# Your data are probably grouped

```{r grouped}
ggplot(data = gapminder,
       mapping = aes(x = year,
                     y = gdpPercap)) +
  geom_line() 
```


```{r grouped-yourturn}

```

# You probably need more than one plot

```{r need}
ggplot(data = gapminder,
       mapping = aes(x = year,
                     y = gdpPercap)) +
  geom_line(aes(group = country)) 
```

Difference between group = and group_by(). We use the group = argument when plotting, telling ggplot that our data are grouped. On the other hand, group_by() is a function that we use to transform a data frame.

```{r need-yourturn}
ggplot(data = gapminder,
       mapping = aes(x = year,
                     y = gdpPercap)) +
  geom_line(aes(group = country))
```


# `facet_wrap()`

```{r wrap}
ggplot(gapminder, aes(x = year, 
                      y = gdpPercap)) + 
  geom_line(color="gray70", aes(group = country)) +
  geom_smooth(size = 1.1, method = "loess", se = FALSE) + # Here, we are using LOESS for smoothing.
  scale_y_log10(labels=scales::dollar) +
  facet_wrap(~ continent, ncol = 5) + # The ~ sign in R is a formula. A data structure in R.
  labs(x = "Year",
       y = "GDP per capita",
       title = "GDP per capita on Five Continents")

# Plot all your data!! Don't do so much data summary that you can't get a sense of what the underlying data look like.
```

```{r wrap-yourturn}
ggplot(gapminder, aes(x = year, 
                      y = gdpPercap)) + 
  geom_line(color="gray70", aes(group = country)) +
  geom_smooth(size = 1.1, method = "loess", se = FALSE) + # Here, we are using LOESS for smoothing.
  scale_y_log10(labels=scales::dollar) +
  facet_wrap(~ country, nrow = 5) +
  labs(x = "Year",
       y = "GDP per capita",
       title = "GDP per capita on Five Continents")
```

# `facet_grid()`

```{r grid}
ggplot(gss_sm,
       aes(x = age, y = childs)) + 
  geom_point(alpha = 0.2) +
  geom_smooth() +
  facet_grid(sex ~ race)
```

```{r grid-yourturn}
ggplot(gss_sm,
       aes(x = age, y = childs)) + 
  geom_point(alpha = 0.7, size = 5) +
  # geom_smooth() +
  facet_grid(race ~ sex)
```

# Arrange multiple plots with patchwork

```{r patch}
p1 <- ggplot(data = penguins, aes(x = flipper_length_mm)) +
  geom_histogram(aes(fill = species),
                 alpha = 0.5,
                 position = "identity") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("darkorange","purple","cyan4")) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(x = "Flipper length (mm)",
       y = "Frequency",
       title = "Plot 1") 

p2 <- ggplot(data = penguins, aes(x=species, 
                                  y = flipper_length_mm, 
                                  fill=species)) +
  geom_violin() + 
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("darkorange","purple","cyan4")) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(y = "Flipper length (mm)",
       x = NULL,
       title = "Plot 2") + 
  theme(legend.position = "none")

p3 <- ggplot(penguins, aes(x = species)) +
  geom_bar(alpha = 0.8) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Plot 3")

p4 <- penguins %>%
  remove_missing() %>% group_by(species) %>% 
  summarise(mean_bmg = mean(body_mass_g)) %>%
  ggplot() +
    geom_segment(aes(x = 0, xend = mean_bmg,
                     y = reorder(species, mean_bmg),
                     yend = reorder(species, mean_bmg)),
                 color = "grey", size = 2) +
    geom_point(aes(y = reorder(species, mean_bmg), x = mean_bmg),
               size = 5, color = "darkorange") +
    labs(x = NULL, y = NULL, title = "Plot 4", 
         subtitle = "Average body mass (g) by species") +
    theme_minimal() +
    theme(plot.title = element_text(face="bold"),
          plot.title.position = "plot")
```

```{r patch-yourturn}
# you don't need to copy above code
# just start arranging plots (p1 to p4) with patchwork
(p1 | p2) / (p3 | p4)
```
